Does anyone else have this happen?
I have had 3 dreams where dream characters have went out of their way to teach me something.
The first was related to sex, so not really relevant to this thread.
The second time I was in a building floating around, and a dream character was like "here, give me your hand". He touched it and my hand turned into this blue quartz-like crystal, a VERY unqiue sensation. Feeling the sensation allowed me to modify my body into crystal at will for the duration of the dream, and it even still partially works in subsequent dreams.
Then this morning there was a woman who was teaching me pyrokinesis. It was very lifelike. The "flames" generated by it (reminded me somewhat of burning air) looked so interesting and unique, not exactly like anythig I have seen before. The flames worked like an aura, if my hands were close together they would form a sphere between them, or if they were separate they would form plumes that sort of look like a mix between a jet afterburner and a gas fireplace.
I remember they showed me something really neat, where if you used it over a steel tunnel you could have a turbine engine sort of effect, which was very cool. She told me that it was possible to make a conical fire vortex without the funnel, but that it took practice. The dream ended before I could learn that skill.
I tried to copy what she taught me irl today, and while it didn't generate flame I did feel an odd sensation in my hands, arm bones, and blood, as well as a strange (non-painful) strained feeling in my heart area.

Does anyone else get dreams like this, where the dream tries to teach you something fantastical or impossible?

>Who is the Nobody?
The Nobody is a figure alive today who has extraordinary spiritual powers, including the ability to influence reality with his conscious and unconscious mind, and intuitively receive guidance from the forces of Heaven.
He is a homoplasmate, a divine syzygy; the coalition between man and holy spirit. That’s the reason why he is a spiritual centre. By homoplasmate I think we can imagine the collective appreciation of a neo-Enochian bicameral consciousness that is rushing into widespread experience.

He works to elevate people to their true potential, opposing those who seek power over others. He's just like you, but he has found the kingdom of God within himself through sheer dedication, just like you will.
He isn't a savior; remember that it's you who creates your own reality. With your hands, thoughts, feelings, words, you are the creator of your story. Old ocean, with waves of crystal, you resemble proportionally to those azure marks that one sees on the bruised back of the mosses; you are an immense blue, applied to the body of the earth: I love this comparison. Thus, at your first sight, a prolonged breath of sadness, which one would think would be the murmur of your sweet breeze, passes, leaving ineffaceable traces, on the soul deeply shaken, and you recall to the memory of your lovers, let us always realize it, the rude beginnings of man, where he becomes acquainted with pain, who never leaves him. I greet you, old ocean!

Old ocean, your harmoniously spherical shape, which rejoices the grave face of geometry, reminds me only too much of the little eyes of man, like those of the wild boar for smallness, and those of the night birds for circular perfection of the contour. However, man has believed himself beautiful in all ages. I suppose rather that man believes in his beauty only through self-love; but that he is not really beautiful and that he suspects it, for why does he look at the face of his fellow with so much contempt? I greet you, old ocean!

Old ocean, you are the symbol of identity: always equal to yourself. You do not vary in an essential way, and if your waves are somewhere furious, farther, in some other zone, they are in complete calm. You are not like the man, who stops in the street, to see two ball-masts clutching his neck, but which does not stop when a funeral passes; which is this morning accessible and this evening in a bad mood; who laughs today and weeps to-morrow. I greet you, old ocean!

around you, and the loneliness you love,

delighting, flashing risk, risk
unfailingly lighting the way,
anything possible
in that dissolving of seam
between minds,
no more golden time—

the right step, words
came to me finally and finding the place
you had set for them,

wrote themselves down.

solid tap of winged blind cane come,

with friends, I see it happening.

when I’m suddenly not; that

and winter while you went about

our conversation resumed.

love passing through me:
I know somehow it will go on
reaching you, reaching you
instantly
when I’m not in the way;
when it is no longer deflected
by all the dark bents, all
I tried to overcome but I could not—
so much light pulled off course
as it passed within reach, so much
lost, lost in me,
but no more.

Doing certain things even without any meaningful desire to do them, only for the sake of "just because".

He starts stretching the limits of his imagination, he plays with his beliefs and destroys any and all meaning that things have to him. The average human brain has about 50 nanograms of dopamine per deciliter. On the best day, that number can near 100. However, we aren't biologically capable of processing more than that. As you probably know, dopamine is the "pleasure" chemical in the brain, and is also released as a reward for completing tasks and whatnot.

Smoke meth, and that number shoots up to around 1100 nanograms per deciliter.

That, and it increases your body temperature, and fucks with your body's ability to regulate temperature, to the point where your brains are literally cooking inside of your skull.

Cessation of a chronic smoker can lead to about 20 nanograms of dopamine/deciliter in the brain. You need at least 40 to be able to want to do literally anything, including getting up out of bed in the morning.

As for connection to the paranormal? Well, you're literally intoxifying your brain to the point of hallucination. And after, developing something akin to dopamine syndrome, if not that it's self. You lose a lot of brainpower, as well.

Meth's kind of demonic. I live in a suburban area. Even high school kids do the shit now, paying an average of 30 dollars a gram.

That's a pretty easily sustainable addiction, compared to more expensive drugs. And a meth high is pretty longevitous comparedly, as well.

Personally, I wish they'd just make amphetamine salts OTC, so the junkies would have a safer alternative. Because the problem is just going to get bigger, and a lot of young and naive lives are going to be completely fucked regardless of if they get caught or not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Is there a difference between the demons and Lucifer and the Devil? That's a very complicated question.

You have to understand that most of the main demons listed in Grimoires originated as pagan deities whose identities were demonized / Stygian-tized (as entities of the underworld) with the spread of Judaism, Islam, and Christianity.

As such, a lot of these deities can put on different cultural masks to fit the worldview or the mythology that the practitioner has chosen to engage in.

For example, the Goddess Aphrodite is identical with the Demon Astaroth. Astaroth was a demonization of the Near Eastern deity Astarte, who was literally that culture's version of Aphrodite; they have a shared historical origin.

Things get complicated with syncretism. Although the substance of their identity as deities most often remain in tact in different cultures, syncretism often results in those masks taking on the characteristics of other deities / myths.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33888847
Lucifer started as the Indo-European morning star deity way, way before Christianity, associated with the Planet Venus; for the Planet Venus was mythologically thought to bring in the light of the day and exile the darkness of night. As such, Lucifer has always been associated with the deity who brings knowledge and enlightenment to mankind (hence his role as the serpent in Genesis 1 and his role as Azazel in the Book of Enoch).

His most crystalized form as Lucifer as the deity whom we know him as was in the form of the Greek deity Phanes (whose name in Greek literally means Lucifer but "light" as in an enlightenment sense), who was the Supreme God of the Orphics - an ascetic but spiritually epicurean sect that sought social responsibility and kindness to all beings, but still sought refined sensual experiences as the highest goal of life. They identified Phanes with Dionysius, the Greek God of wine drinking, music, and eroticism, and saw him as the creator deity - they saw the fire of human desire that moves civilization forward as the spark of the divine itself. They also connected Phanes to that Morning Star God who brought enlightenment from the heavens.

The Mithraics stole a lot from the Orphics.

The Christians were in direct competition with both the Orphics and Mithraics in Rome as a "mystery school" sect and one for the time being, and part of their propaganda was demonizing the deity Phanes as Satan. They identified Phanes as Satan by reference to Isaiah 14, because they saw the same name "Lucifer" in that verse and connected it to that sect; "Hey you, you claim that Phanes is the Supreme Deity, but it says here in our magical book that Lucifer (Helel / Phanes) is actually Satan who wanted to overthrow God! You are worshipping the Devil!"

For that reason Lucifer became crystalized as Satan in Christianity.

So Satan, as part of the Judeo-Christian mythos, is synonymous with Lucifer if you choose to work through that cultural system.

>>33883871
Look up "kebatinan". The root word "bātin" is Arabic and means "inner" among other things. Malay silat inherited esoteric aspects of Islam, but also retains some Shaiva-Buddhist elements from those religions that Malay people practiced before the arrival of Islam. Filipinos also have similar admixtures, but because Christianity won out in that sphere, the esoteric aspects (if any) of stuff like Escrima and Kali tends to have more of a Christian flavor. A lot of that stuff is Bullshido, so browse with a discerning eye.

I have no idea how to precisely calculate the information/entropy sacrifice that you'd do by purposefully focusing on something like a prayer, but for fun I calculated the entropy of thinking of a maximum of 7 things at once out of 1 billion possible ones (working memory) plus the maximum entropy of a 206-character sentence (comparable to a short prayer like Hail Mary)

posts.com:
>>33886683
How do you calculate the amount generated/output

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33887167
Shannon entropy, basically
Since every random byte I generate is equally likely as any other byte, I get 8 bits of entropy per random byte
Multiply 8 bits per byte times 1024 bytes in a kilobyte by 1024 kilobytes in a megabyte by 1024 megabytes in a gigabyte and you get a real big number of entropy bits

There was, but the tradition is mostly lost, or buried in obscure mostly untranslated (Arabian) alchemical treatises. Certain practices (omphalos psychism etc) survives at Athos, allegedly stemming from pre-Christian neoplatonic methods, but these are locked away from outsiders. Some claim that Gurdjieff's contemplative methods (which where not published until recently) are modiciations of Athos tech. These involve breathing execercises & various manipulations of occult forces in order to effect inner alchemical changes of the human "factory", in order to 'coat' and 'develop' the embryos of higher being bodies, somewhat similar to daoist neidan.

>>33892189
>gravy

Skill level: entry
Cornstarch, xanthum gum, arrow root, etc. quick and easy, usually need to simmer/boil for a minute to cook it.

Skill level: intermediate
Heavy cream is one way. Can also use whole milk. Neither of these are quick, because you have to let them reduce down at a low temperature until it is thick enough. If you have the temp too high or you're not stirring enough you will burn it.

Skill level: advanced
Egg yolks are a great thickener. If you've ever made pudding or ice cream then you may be familiar with this. Separate the yolk from the white. Break the yolk and slowly temper your hot liquid into the egg yolk, slowly because if you do it quickly you will curdle it (think scrambled) and it will not thicken. Once the yolk/hot liquid is combined and not curdled then you can slowly pour it back into the hot pan with the rest of the sauce while whisking vigourously. Gently bring to a simmer while whisking and it will thicken.

Yes. There are many parallels between Shani and Saturn, such that it is reasonable to presume that both are divergent understandings from a previous source.
Shanivasara, for instance, is the seventh day of the Hindu week.
Although the order of the celestial realms is a little different in Vedic understanding. In descending order:
Saturn
Jupiter
Mars
Mercury
Venus
Moon
Sun
Earth
Vedic astrologers tried to be very detailed about the positions and movements of the planets. But outside the planetary connection, I would not claim a lot of similarity between the personalities Shani and Saturn.

The first guy to promote the idea that the Kaaba is a tool of a Demiurge like being was John Keel in his book The Eight Tower, which came out in 1975. Keel btw had self-professed ties to intelligence and is described as some combination of gullible paranoid, cynical hack/hoaxer, and spooky manipulator by basically everyone who knew him.

Then in the 90s, David Icke and Jordan Maxwell created a neo-Gnostic mythology that used that same idea and expanded on it. Then in the 2000s and 2010s, guys like Troy McLachlan came along and combined the pseudo-Gnostic Saturn mythos with electric universe. This is the version that took off on 4chan, maybe because fringier far right podcasts like Red Ice had guys like McLaghlan on back in the day, definitely at least partially because the conspiracy/mythos was always directed against Muslims and is easily directed against Jews (although you see cubes in Christianity as well, look at Rev 21:16).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33891347
Electric universe itself goes back way further than Saturn death cult Gnostic crap, to the late 19the century and the writings of a guy called Immanuel Vellikovsky. Vellikovsky said that there'd been some sort of cosmic cataclysm ages ago and earth orbited Saturn before that, but didn't bring any conspiratorial angle, he was just a weird fringe science guy, tons of them in the 1800s. Then in the 1970s you get David Talbott and a couple other people who try to rehabilitate Vellikovsky, bring in more of a mythological element, and then eventually EU gets merged with SDC in the 00s, probably just because people watching guys like Icke and Maxwell start "researching" Saturn and find Talbott.

It's pretty fascinating history, always thought that it sucks that you have to trace conspiracy culture/fringe science ideas yourself, it's interesting and important enough that there should be academic chairs devoted to it.

But yeah, seems to be a combination of well meaning kooks like Vellikovsky, disinfo agents like Keel, occultists selling repackaged Gnosticism and Theosophy like Icke, and people doing lazy research.

>>33885617
The general instruction is to do it until you have truly felt it to be real (not necessarily until you receive it in this 3D world).

As the ladder experiment points out, that doesn't mean that you have no doubts about it during the course of your regular day - simply, you have experienced it as an undeniable fact in SATS and carry that through until the situation arises. When doubt comes, you can simply relax, smile, and recall the feeling of the wish fulfilled.

When I say relax, there's a band that stretches around the brain and down the spine (the meninges), during meditation find that muscle and develop the relaxation of it, then move to practicing that relaxation in daily life. It makes everything a lot easier in my experience.

>>33891056
Sorry for being harsh, but that's kind of dumb. If you're going to be talking about masculine and active signs then it makes no sense to ignore the traditional designation. If Sagittarius is the sign of the wanderer or adventurer, Gemini is the sign of the trickster or "manipulator" (in the objective rather than the social sense). It's not a coincidence that Gemini rules the arms. As the third sign in the zodiac, Gemini also invokes the symbolism of the number three, which symbolises the emergence of self-awareness and the manipulation and control over other things. A lot of the active and masculine archetypes you find in modern fiction, like the lovable rogue, for example, can be much more closely identified with Gemini than with Sagittarius. At its best, Gemini is an insightful and strategic sign, and at its worst it is a cunning and malicious one. It seems unfair to me to reduce it only to the ideas of superficiality and unreliability - it entirely depends on the situation and the manifestation (like which house and what planets are involved). In mutable-type situations I think you'd be hard pressed to find a sign that does better than Gemini.

>>THE DOCTRINE OF TRANSITS

>The horoscope doesn't describe what there is before birth, nor what there is after death, although you can admit that aspects (directions) in regression, and in succession of death, can indicate certain phenomena external in relation to life, so to say, pre-natal and post-mortal of the individual. >Life is essentially action, and what the horoscope indicates is the action there is in the life of the native. There's three things not to look for in the horoscope: (1) the fundamental qualities of the individual, as to his intimite degree; (2) the social starting point of his life; (3) what results of him, and the life that he had, after death. Everything, but this, does the horoscope include and define.
>Let's not be amazed that it is uninteresting and ordinary the horoscope of a great artist that was only celebrated after death: the horoscope will indicate artistic qualities (to a degree we cannot measure) and will indicate obscurity. Everything will be indicated in abstract; only our own foresight will realize it. (Such is the meaning of Ptolemy's first apothem.)
>Better exemplifying: a horoscope of a dramatic poet may be determined as it also may , within the same horoscope, be indicated a certain fame and a certain profit. That aside, it can be the horoscope of Shakespeare or that of a dramatic poet of inferior note, that, in the era that he lived in, had had a life, as far as fame and profit, identical or similar to that of Shakespeare. The horoscope reveals, little more or less, what he worlds sees. Never must we forget this detail of utmost importance. Without it we'll make nothing of astrology.

You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33806643
>How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?
You recognize a "full blown lucid dream" by your mental clarity, not what you're able to do. In full lucid dreams you have the same kind of sharp thinking as in real life, able to fully self-reflect and process thoughts as in waking life. In what you call dreams ibetween it's more like you're a zombie with a vague notion that there are no consequences for your actions.

>>33807184
If you're religious, you might benefit from thinking lucid dreaming is some kind of magic phenomena, since it will make it feel more real. If you want to just DILD, do the boring basic shit like keeping a dream journal, reality checks, and MILD before bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
well gents, new year new goals. something i wish to take seriously this year is something i've come to call "wake-sleeping", although i suppose a more fitting name might simply be "lucid sleeping".

the concept is quite simple: remain aware whenever the body sleeps. it would certainly be similar to WILD, except it takes place at bed time, and ends when you would normally wake up; the ultimate goal being, to completely and entirely decouple consciousness from sleep. the most advanced form of this practice, theoretically, would result in one who never lapses in consciousness, 24/7 awareness.

i've made some progress on making this work, but it's obviously hard. it is certainly possible, however, and so i remain confident in its feasibility, but the trial and error is long and grueling.

i will keep updates in these threads as meaningful developments occur, as this intersects plainly with lucid dreaming (engaging in this practice successfully would have a side effect of making ALL dreams lucid).

posts.com:
I accidentally went directly into a lucid dream without even trying
>Woke up in the middle of the night, probably because I took 2 valerian root capsules before bed
>Can't really get back to sleep
>Figure I'll just do some imagination and visualization
>Spend an unspecified amount of time focusing while imagining things, it was a long time
>Ok, time to go to bed
>Lie on my back and relax
>Hypnagogia starts almost immediately, white fuzz forms into snow falling over a river during nighttime
>Realize what is happening, imagine where I want to be
>I am in my house, it's the middle of the day, for whatever reason I am short, as tall as a toddler
>There are people yelling outside (my room is on the second story), I look down at them, my relatives have arrived in a couple trucks, decide to go out of my room and look around the house as a small person
>My cousin is outside of my door, she is much taller than me
>Can see up her skirt, slap her ass and run past her, she doesn't notice
>Walk around my house for a bit, neat seeing how it is from this tall
>I lose focus and the dream shifts into black. At this moment I don't put in the effort to shift it back into something and just wake up
So overall I knew I was dreaming and could control what I was doing but for whatever reason I had the feeling that I should wake up and sleep properly, so I did. I'm sure if I was actually planning to lucid dream I would have stayed in there but I was tired and it didn't really matter at the time.
I'm theorizing that spending a bunch of time just "imagining" stuff and getting lost in your fantasy world will vastly improve the chances of entering the right state to do this, this was actually the first time for me being in the hypnagogic state and I didn't even try for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33878876 >>33878852
your mind doesn't fall asleep all at once, it follows a very specific route
as you relax at first proprioception will be turned off [your ability to feel the position of your limbs] then nociception and thermoception turn off [your ability to sense pain and sensing temperature] and finally kinesthesicepion and equilibrioception will turn off [your ability to feel motion and your orientation]
while there are more things that turn off after these two, those two are almost a perfect setup to either fall asleep right there or just enter a wild
i used to have a really hard time falling asleep until i figured this out dayo

that's a strange question dayo
when the first one turns off you will only feel points of contact, normally when you put your hand behind your back you know its there even though you can't see it, so when proprioception is turned off you would only feel the hand if its making contact with your back
when thermoception is off you either won't feel warm or cold anymore or you will feel really warm even if you really aren't
kinesthesicepion feels like you're in motion, usually spinning or falling

>>33887289
Aphantasia has nothing to do with dreaming. Dreams are not created in your minds eye, they are created using the same process that you use in your waking life but without the external stimuli. They are more accurately compared to hallucinations than imagination. That's why you require sleep paralysis to stop you from moving and why your real eyes follow the movement of your dream eyes.

Also it's worth pointing out almost all studies that have tested it have shown that aphantasia can be fixed with simple practice. Don't be one of these people that just wallows in a completelypyxshk preventable "handicap".

yeah, because murnau wasn't a subversive degenerate weimar turbokike himself or anything... however, that being said, nosferatu and faust are both excellent films and personal favorites of mine. i'd also recommend carl theodore dreyer's vampyr as well. fun fact: lon chaney was originally slated to play the lead role in tod browning's dracula but unfortunately died before this could happen. and it's too bad too because this would have undoubtedly been a much better film starring chaney and also in all likelihood would've altered the course of vampire films as we know them. among other things i like nosferatu because it's depicts vampires as they should be - gross, creepy, evil fucking monsters and jewish as all get out. not any of this gay, moody, forlorn, woe is me, romanticized faggotry with a "handsome" vampire that makes the ladies swoon and your supposed to (i guess) sympathize with in some weird way. that's bullshit. one other little tidbit while i'm thinking about it... you may not know this but lon chaney did actually make one talkie before his death - a remake of tod browning's the unholy three. he also starred in the original silent version which was quite excellent and it also featured the midget who later played hans in browning's freaks. anyways, the remake wasn't directed by browning for some reason and frankly kinda sucked but it's worth checking out i guess just because, as i said, it was chaney's only talkie. ...and he doesn't have a weird voice or anything if you were wondering. sounded perfectly normal. also, from what i've heard, chaney grew up with both his parents being deaf, which i suppose might explain why he was so effective at expressing so much without the use of sound. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson: https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel. Beware that this book is rather dark, and some have mentioned attracting unwanted attention by reading it.
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

posts.com:
>>33890394
in case you are unfamiliar with the series, it takes place in a fictional reimagining of the modern world, some 200 years after a global nuclear war left most of the world an irradiated hellhole
the player character's identity, as far as the rest of the world is concerned, is Courier 6, the 6th courier hired for a job delivering casino themed baubles to New Vegas, a glittering city of lights in the nearly lifeless desert.
this character is an allegory for azazel: he is cast into darkness (the screen goes black) is when he is robbed and shot by the Christ allegory, Benny (more on that later) and has sharp and rough stones placed upon him (the cemetary where this occurs can be visited in game, and the pile next to the open grave is largely comprised of stones) in the desert. He brings war (the events of the game culminate in a decisive battle between two powerful factions) and is largely an agent of chaos.

Mr. House is the person who hired the Courier, and is an allegory for God. he is very powerful and wise, having saved the mojave from something nearly 100 atomic bombs during the great war. for much of the game, he only appears in images and sound, and requires a human agent to do his bidding. all major quest lines require you to kill him, except for the line where you choose to work for him directly. people aren't even sure if he really exists.

there's a ton more, but i have to head in to work. if the thread's still up when I'm on break, I'll drop more.

>>33891888
checked; and congratulations on your conversion to zionism

i pick that DLC because the symbolism is both in your face and subtle
the question you are being asked to decide in that DLC is the question of zionism: or, rather, the question of whether it is the physical life of a people (as represented by the land upon which theh live) that takes precedence, or the spiritual life; is Israel a nation of the spirit, or one of clay?
graham is the zionist choice--obviously, he prefers the people to stay in Zion, no matter the cost to their spirit. he is further bolstered by being a much stronger figure than his spiritual antithesis: much fire and brimstone, a steely certainty and a stark character design all seem intended to draw the player to his cause. daniel, by contrast, lies to his people (for their own benefit, he claims), is very soft-spoken, his character design could be reasonably substituted with any NPC in the game, and his resolve seems wavering--though he is very adamant about his charges leaving Zion, the only opposition he mounts is to whinge about your choice and its implications. further, even if you do side with him, he spends the rest of his days wondering if he was really right. in game terms, too, you are incentivized to side with Graham; siding with Daniel renders Zion sterile and lifeless, and none of the harvestable plants will regrow, which makes one of the biggest benefits for completing the DLC moot.

the tribe that graham and daniel belong to are called 'new caananites' and, while they are ostensibly mormons, they refer to people not of their tribe as 'gentiles' and never reference Christ, even in passing or obliquely
and, while i confess i know less of the bible than i should, neither man references the new testament at all as far as i am aware; every bit of scripture discussed or referenced is from the old testament.

tl;dr: sorry bro, you're a shabbos goy now

in the original The Witcher, the in-game Alchemy component uses the names and (very rough) descriptions from real-world alchemy, though I couldn't begin to tell you how faithful it is to genuine alchemy in terms of how ingredients combine. it is actually fun trying to figure out ways to produce the potions you want with better combinations of ingredients, though the game does get a bit sloggish and grindy. I actually quite enjoyed the story, as far as I got--my computer died when I was past the second act but before I finished, and I only recently got a new one.
mind, this was the product that launched CDPR onto the map, back when they were a small polish game company. the game was actually programmed with cards featuring nude female characters and depicted sex acts. The game was censored, but people broke it to see them. I have the files for that fix sitting around in a dusty old email inbox somewhere.

>>33848290
I'd suggest that everyone who meditates or wants to start meditating to ask himself the question: Why am I meditating/Why I want to meditate?
So yeah, ask yourself that question.

Ask yourself: Why I want to open my chakras or manipulate energy?

I'm suggesting this because people get into meditation to either chase illusions and other ego-stuff (like goals) or to try and escape from illusions (fears, trauma etc), I think that this is wrong and that meditation should be used for the exact opposite: To realize that all of that are illusions and nothing more.

I'd suggest to just sit and be aware of your body sensations, of your body being there and breathing, not analyzing it or controlling it but totally letting it go and just watching it. This is the basis of the meditative state: Being aware.

But don't put words into it, don't make goals, just do it everyday and stay there.
Depending on who you are this may take some time.

And lastly to also answer your question: You "open chakras" by focusing on them, yeah, meditation is a physical practice not a mental one, you sit to sense and feel so just sit and feel the chakras.

However I'd suggest that first you sit to silence the mind by being still and aware.
Good luck.

>>33853173
There is no division between mindfulness and meditation. Mindfulness is a word that was taken from western spiritual traditions to translate the word "Sati", and it was re-adopted by western society for largely marketing purposes. It's a cozy word. Really, meditation (samadhi) is a focused application of mindfulness (sati). There is no meditation without mindfulness; samma samadhi is the result of samma sati. The Satipatthana sutta is the frame within which all other meditation methods occur in. To be mindful is to keep something in mind, and in Buddhism that's within the framework of the four satipatthana.

I haven't been trained in Zen but I have experience serving retreats at Thai Forest monasteries, where I did read some books on Zazen... the gist I got was that we "just sit to sit" or "sitting is good for nothing". While I can't say how accurate my understanding is, I think this is helpful for times when you get too caught up in goals to the point where you're stressing yourself out, in which case it may be wise to just get back to the bare bones: sitting. But doing that for a while, your mind gets a bit listless or confused, in which case it's helpful to remember why you're practicing in the first place. But sometimes to go deep you have to put aside the part of the mind which is constructing goals and reasons for focusing attention. In a way you have to "just do it". Think Solid Snake in Metal Gear Solid: "Don't think, shoot!"

But in any case, there is mindfulness: remembering to "just sit" or remembering the 16 steps of Anapanasati. You need to read your own mind, so to speak, to see what's good for you. But mindfulness is always there until the end. Sometimes we just get too self conscious about it (which is what the mindfulness industry seems to profit off of).

>>33848290
One of the best uses of meditation is training focused contemplation. You do this through sitting, eyes closed, breathing, and every time you stop paying attention to your breath, you recognize it and pull your attention back to your breathing. It starts with that. Eventually, feel free to let yourself off the leash a little and mentally wander around during your meditation. Something to be cautious of is accidentally developing a dissociative disorder. Be mindful of when that feeling starts to develop and work through it in a healthy way. If you navigate that properly, you have crossed a really powerful milestone in building your skill. If you don't arrive at that point, you haven't been meditating long enough or seriously enough. It's worth getting into, but don't let it consume you. Meditation for me has been at its most beautiful when it feels spontaneous and unplanned. It's ugly when you treat it like it's something you have to pencil in: "oh it's time for my 5 minute 4:00 PM meditation!" When it's just like "hmmm I feel like this is a good time to meditate" that's when I tend to have my best sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33857923
There's a point in that kind of goal-less practice where you're actually kind of just feeding whatever is going on, if you aren't considering your input in the experience. It's like having the TV turned to static and just letting it sit like that forever. Giving your mind an object to focus on and refine, such as the breath "energy", gets you deeper.

But being aware of those things is crucial - you just need to stop giving them input if they're causing too much movement or darker states of mind. Instead of seeing thoughts just as some things which happen, see how they arise due to things within your control (your volitional thoughts and way of seeing things, posture, etc). Learn to use those things to relax the body while brightening and stilling the mind.

Once you've become absorbed in the body, things are much more clearer and expansive. Sometimes there is a sense of great space (you can focus on that to develop it, too).

It's important to balance effort and relaxation here. Too much effort or striving and you just get uptight and frustrated. Too much relaxation, you fall asleep or get lazy and dull. In a way you need to let the breath do the work... "allow it" to soften, fill the body, etc. Release the blockages and tight spots and let the body feel more still.

In Eastern spiritual schools there are two approaches, one is through gradual training with different stages and the other is spontaneous, instant liberation.
Lazy people can do the instant cutting-through approach and reach enlightenment that way, diligent and neurotic people will still need to rely on the gradualist way of meditation to step by step calm their minds.
So if you feel that there is a problem preventing you from seeing the natural state and you have an antidote at hand, apply it.
Because this is a gradual path you'll want to practice the meditation a lot and step by step lessen your dependence on your focus aids.

Some things to look into are the Anapanasati Sutta, the Satipatthana Sutta, Vitakka-santhana Sutta, and the Ahara Sutta (on the hindrances, factors of awakening). They generally have a good framework and a good translation provides good phrasing that's good for remembering.

Balancing effort and relaxation is kind of a thing everyone struggles with on a day-to-day basis and there's no clear-cut way to do it, you have to feel your way into it. But if you develop a somewhat methodical approach to meditation (through continuous practice) it begins to make more sense.

For me I just sit down, get comfy, focus on breathing but also the state of my mind: whether it's contracted or expanded etc (see Satipatthana). Just to get a sense of things. Then I put a little more attention to the breathing and feel it out for tight spots and softer spots. In general the quality of the breath is connected to certain feelings, emotions, thought patterns etc, which may need to be addressed specifically, but sometimes just working with the breath to soothe it and the body is helpful enough. Naturally the body kind of relaxes and the mind gets quieter and more steady.

This is how I do it after a long time of struggling with that balance (although I can't say it's totally "solved" as there is always more room for refinement). At the beginning I was just kind of watching the mind as it is, then after like two years of that I realized I was going nowhere and tried to get a little more methodical. At that point I began to try too hard and get too uptight, so I gradually just began to realize that being observant and "doing" things worked hand in hand. One important thing for me was realizing that much of what we want in meditation are the results. But you don't "get" results, instead you do things which bring results. That entails taking the basic methods, having some goals, and experimenting with the methods to see what happens. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865549
Along those lines, (at least from the Buddhist POV) the key principles are the four noble truths: There is suffering, its cause, its cessation, and the way leading to cessation.

Generally people start meditating because they're stressed somehow or want something better. Right there they may see how suffering is arising as a result of something they are doing. While the root is craving, this manifests as well in thoughts and perceptions we choose to believe.

By experimenting with our thoughts and perceptions in meditation (e.g. replacing thoughts of anger with thoughts of kindness; replacing thoughts of lust with contemplation of asubha or reflection on drawbacks; replacing scattered thoughts with focused thoughts about the breath) we can see how, in turn, those new thoughts or ideas influence the mind to bring it in a new direction.

So the direction of the mind is not something we can latch onto and force one way or another, but rather we need to look at the causes and begin to exert influence on those.

Here is where effort and relaxation again need to be balanced. E.g. thinking of kindness as hard as we can won't generate good feelings and get rid of all of our anger. First we need to be patient and stick with basics, which may just be chanting or repeating phrases from the Karaniya Metta Sutta. Then we need to see what the results are of that over a period of practice.

I often compare it to Tai Chi. In the beginning we must learn basic choreography as well as postural basics. If we speed through the form without basics we can injure ourselves no matter how much we talk about "moving meditation" and "flow". The basics must slowly, gradually, and patiently be developed over time. Then we find that the appearance of flow is only external, and the real internal stuff has to do with our mind and connection to the body, and what we do with that. At first it seems like a lot, but after continuous development it all comes together naturally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865632
To simplify: If you're up in your head a lot, just try being more mindful of the body. Do more physical activities (work, exercise, going outside), and meditate on the breath.

Although there's plenty of nuances that need to be developed, sometimes it's helpful to just think of relaxing with awareness of breathing. As we get better and more steady with this, the deeper stuff becomes more doable.

If we find that external circumstances are stressful, breathing meditation may help but from the Buddhist POV we also need to consider our lifestyle and every day decisions to bring us to a better overall place for practice.

>>33853135
I really like that book, first I thought he just had a great editor but if you listen to his talks you can tell that it's his voice. First of all, I think he does a great job at teaching anapanasati, and that by itself takes one a long way. That being said, the book (and I checked out his other material, they are the same) falls short in two ways. One, he seemingly uses metta in his practice heavily, yet the way he teaches that is not great because he tries to teach it exactly as described in the suttas. Second, from what I understood, he exclusively uses kasina meditation in specific ways to go into certain jhanas, yet he only mentions that in passing, as in "oh by the way some people think about circular things while meditating," which makes no sense in the context so you probably brushed that off (I'm not saying that kasina meditation is important and you should do it but rather he doesn't practice what he teaches). This is mostly because how kasina meditation is supposed to be done is not elaborated in the suttas and he doesn't want to go off the book. Both of these issues are caused by the same thing, he's dogmatic about suttas, as most serious Theravadan people.
So to someone who has read that book, I would advise two things. Metta is important, try to find a way to make that work for yourself, both the exact method to do it and how to incorporate that into your sessions. If you're having trouble stilling your mind, this is especially relevant. The second thing is notice the importance of jhanas and the fact that the main goal is to spend as much time as possible in jhana. My understanding based on research is that this is the case and Bhante Gunaratana also teaches this in his other material, but he probably didn't dwell on it in a beginner's book considering that it's an advanced subject.

After most of my issues were resolved I was way softer as a person, then I began seeing clearly what reality is, how things REALLY work, I could now look at a tree and be amazed that such a thing exists, I was somehow alive again.

Sorry for the wall of text but I like speaking about my short history now and then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let's forget everything you think you believe for one second except for some core ideas that most of us are pretty much agreed upon.
>Reincarnation/karma
>The existence of the astral plane, the power of dreams etc.
>ESP abilities such as telepathy etc.
>The symbolic and synchronous nature of reality

I see on here many theories and wild concepts that draw some pretty gloomy conclusions about the nature of our reality such as the prison planet idea, malevolent aliens, parasitic demons, pedos that run the world etc.
I'm not here to claim that any of those are untrue but for me I find that considering those possibilities too much in my worldview tends to muddy the waters. I try to stick to what I know or fundamentally believe. For instance reincarnation makes a lot of sense to me and makes me feel a lot better about things. What also makes me feel better about things is that there are quite a lot of good and worthwhile experiences to have on this planet. To tell you the truth as much as I am generally having a pretty bad time in life and yearn for much more, I am attached to this planet and the idea of sticking around for at least one more life here in order to experience what I want to experience here. Every reality is unique and flawed. This one is probably far from the worst one. There are probably infinite different realities we will have the pleasure/misfortune to experience. All in all I think it's a pretty fun ride despite the pain and tedium. I think you guys need to lighten up a bit and get out of your heads maybe. This is coming from someone who wants to kill myself every day by the way. I'm not one to say "just be happy" but I do believe that in the grand scheme of things it's not that bad. This place has made for a pretty good story if not for anything else. And there are some pretty wild lessons to be had.

Pic unrelated

I'm not exactly sitting on a super-computer here, but my best guestimation is that beyond the event horizon time becomes a spatial dimension.
i.e., all roads lead to the singularity, there's no direction you can possibly travel that doesn't end up there.
Though, hypothetically, if you were to somehow survive that descent, you could turn around and look back out, and you'd see the entire history of the universe flash before your eyes. That's a consequence of this.
Then there's the matter of the singularity itself. I don't have any idea what that is. My crude calculations just fucking break.
So, maybe it's literally the entire universe, or maybe it's time compressed to such a degree that everything goes 'backwards' in an instant. In other words, the entire lifetime of the entire universe plays out backwards in time as we know it, and you end up at the big bang. The shortest possible increment of time inside is the largest increment of time outside.
Information isn't destroyed if it's send "back" in time... It only appears to be because it's suddenly outside of our causal horizon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What we really need is the ability to produce tiny black holes to study how they evaporate.
This would tell us a great deal about their inner workings.
The problem with studying the evaporation of black holes is that the bigger they are, the longer it takes them to evaporate.
A black hole with the mass of say, a baseball, would take billions of years to evaporate. That's not a convenient time frame for us.
What we need are black holes with the mass of say, an electron.
Then we could watch them evaporate in real time.
It is in principle possible to do this, though it's not exactly practical. We just need some kind of particle collider the size of the orbit of Mars.
We're obviously not going to build that, so we need some other option.
It doesn't actually have to be a solid tube that size, I mean, space is already a vacuum...
Again, I don't have the computing power to really see this through, but there's a faint glimmer of hope that we could somehow accelerate particles to relativistic speeds in orbit around the sun using some kind of high power EM beams to aim them at one another.
This technology is... well, it's frankly beyond us at this point, but in principle it's possible.
If we could like, build a laser array with more power than the nuclear stockpile of all of Earth, and somehow aim it to the precision of an atom at a distance of a planetary orbit, we could construct a sort of 'free floating' atom smasher that could do this.

The more I learn about magic, the more I realize Rowling really has studied the subject in depth. Of course the magic described in the books is fictional and you can't use it, but some of the things she writes are a wink and a nod to adepts.

For example the Patronus spell, were you invoke the positive emotions of your happiest memory — that's a trick used in European folk magic.

I suspect she actually used magic to make them bestsellers. Probably formulae to improve her own creativity and productive energy, and probably some spells for financial success.

Which all worked quite miraculously when you compare those books to other YA fiction. They're really no better than hundreds of other novels at the top of the genre. It's hard to account for the absolute craze the public had for them.

Does anyone wonder what death is like? Or what dying is like? I have good answers to those questions.
I was murdered by four under the full moon back in 2021. I gave a prayer to Lord Shiva, and he let me live.
The experience of dying is not one of panic, nor one of anger, nor of fear or grief. It is one of peace - tranquility knowing the finality of these moments, and an appreciation for the beauty of the world, even in times of death like the one you are the protagonist of.
Past the curtain of life, there is not. It is dark. But it is warm. It is not suffering, it is peace. It is tranquility and knowledge that you have done what you were supposed to, and that your life's struggles are over. But perhaps that is what awaited for me because my life was not over. But those few moments of death were ones of peace.

I came across a few strong challenges raised against a subset of experiences, within Near Death Experiences, in the context of artificial structures and I'd like to post them here.

If the entities in control of this place are running a simulation, then is it possible that there are fake constructs built specifically for the soul, an illusory hologram triggered after the soul leaves the body? Like the "light of the end of the tunnel" that is apparently seen as we die, that concept is talked about being a soul trap and that you shouldn't "go to the light" at all. Many NDEs are touching and heartfelt. An aspect that may give deeper legitimacy to the personal accounts are the strong emotions coupled with expanded awareness, and scale of the cosmos and the Creator, if the soul goes that far. Can the encounters of passed loved ones, the Creator and most importantly, *specifically* Jesus Christ be believed? Take a moment to appreciate the powerful impact of these experiences and the profound emotions that accompany them.

https://youtu.be/CkUYCsw0HrM

NDEs are described to vary according to cultural and religious background, suggesting that "the program" can tailor a fake experience to your personal beliefs. That question can easily turn into a bigger question altogether, "Can spiritual experiences be believed when there are so many masters of illusions operating as we speak?" Consequently "How can a spiritual experience be verified?"

"The Veil of Forgetfulness" and Reincarnation

So... you're clearly a deep thinker, and I like deep thinkers.

Firstly, yes, there are illusions in place to greet most people post-death. These illusions, including the tunnel of light, come from higher dimensional negative beings, or luciferian light beings, as a disguise in order to lure in souls.

i encountered a sasquatch last year in the northern cascades while hiking alone.
i took a video of it.
then after that i was overcome with dread so i ran and somehow got lost 3 miles up this mountain for over an hour, slipping and sliding down this steep grade, holding on to branches and bushes.
And while i was lost there was about a dozen tree knocks in total, following me from the left and right.
anyways, i sat down finally and asked in my mind “sasquatch, can you help me find the trail? i’m lost and just want to go to back to camp”
i had nothing to lose, i just thought that and sent it away and kept walking.

so as i’m heading down, holding on to branches because of the steepness of the slope, and i hear this massive ROAR from over my right shoulder.
it reverberated my entire chest and body and was so terrifying, i instinctively turned left to get away from the noise.
i was too scared to even look back, it sounded like a fucking lion, and i’m heading left now instead of down.
about 100 yards later i reach a small cliff and find the trail.

As i’m walking down the trail, i’m looking over to the right where i was lost, and the mountain gave way to huge steep gravely and loose shale cliffs. if i had continued even another 100 yards, i would’ve easily slipped and fallen to my death or serious injury.

so whatever made that roar that forced me to turn left at that exact moment saved my life.

I feel incredibly humbled and lucky to have had this experience. i got a video of it, it showed itself to me, because right before the encounter i was singing songs about sasquatch and how i want to see one.
These things are real, and they are more than animals.

>>33892535
>"To those who seek Victory [in Warfare] I am Morality" -- Krishna, the Bhagavad-Gita
I would dispute your interpretation.
Gita 10.38
daṇḍo damayatām asmi
nītir asmi jigīṣatām
maunaṁ caivāsmi guhyānāṁ
jñānaṁ jñānavatām aham
>Among all means of suppressing lawlessness I am punishment, and of those who seek victory I am morality. Of secret things I am silence, and of the wise I am the wisdom.
Krishna is in this chapter declaring Himself to be the superlatives of various categories.
>punishment (literally "stick") is the best means of suppressing lawlessness
>silence is the best keeper of secrets
In other verses, he says things like "of fish I am the shark".
So when he says "to those seeking victory" - any type of victory - the superlative is morality. A justified, a righteous victory is the best kind of victory.

It's a bit ironic when you look to the later parts of the Mahabharata and what happens in the actual battle. Krishna encourages the Pandavas and their compatriots to break rules and "cheat" to match the deviations from the Kauravas.
Even Krishna - after vowing before the battle to not take up arms and fight - uses a loophole to pick up a chariot wheel (technically not a weapon, though His famed weapon is the Chakra - which means "wheel") to attack Bhisma so that Arjuna may survive the encounter.

But even with all that, the Pandavas still had the overall morality of the entire situation on their side.
It's part of what makes the Mahabharata one of my favorite religious texts. The entire thing is a study in
>okay, we know the basic tenets of dharma
>but what about THIS complex situation?
>what do you do when dharma seems to contradict itself?

posts.com:
Every fiction writing is in one way or another an esoteric writing. Can we agree on that? Sure, genre conventions exist, but everything boils down to the fact that fiction is not just a description of the author's surroundings.... it's a description of a better and more sustainable world!

Today the most important issue would be the production of Hitlerian (or Italian Fascist) fiction. We do not have to “be Hitler” or “recreate” Hitler: indeed that would bore the very person we look up to. So we must write something that can be read with the same enjoyment both by the Author, by Hitler, and by a bored girl looking for an exciting book in her neighborhood library.

Is it hard? Not really. Maybe the only tip you'll need is "the halfway point between The Coming Race and The Turner Diaries". But we must still be vigilant to avoid certain pitfalls. We can maintain our vigilance by observing certain landmarks that helped our people in the past:

1. True, Good & Beautiful Diversity (TGBD)
This is the opposite of the "mud-diversity" promoted by the communists. TGBD comes to life when we must prescribe desirable looks and behaviors only in the broadest and most essential brushstrokes, while taking care to highlight the absence of negative looks and behaviors. After all, do you care more about a person giving you a certain password, or that said person is not a liar, not filthy, not annoying, and does not mix with people you would prefer to avoid? Do you care more if he is sometimes late for work, or that he has never stolen from his employer (who is a good man and upstanding citizen)? Do you care that she is sweaty after working out or that she is so healthy that her sweat is more pure than the tears of subhuman communists?

Long story short: we would like all kinds of people in the Hitlerian or Fascist state. We want MAXIMUM DIVERSITY! But a diversity of beauty & strengths, NOT a diversity of disease & ways to be disgusting (like what the communists groomers desire)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2. Set it in some nice period
Mass surveillence and cellphones/smartphones are not nice things and should not be part of any desirable décor. A good society has the resources to right any wrong and to apprehend any criminal using just the skills and initiative of the individuals investigating said crime. In other words, cowardice and manipulation on an industrial scale dirties the holy triumvirate of human dignity: the power of heart, the power of mind, and the power of a healthy body that is crowned by sharp senses.
Just as a suggestion, such nice periods are: the years 1000 to 1700, the second industrial revolution (1870 to 1920), the 1930's and 1940's in Germany, Italy, and France, the 1950's 1960's 1970's 1980's and the 1990's in the USA (you can go up until 2006 or 2007 even), 1980's and 1990's Japan.
Where you focus, what your characters are doing, and what is the general state of the world is very important. Did Germany, Italy, & Japan win WW2 or lose: are you building up a new wave or sweeping off the last remnants of scum? Would you be a powerful heiress looking for a husband in the 1920's or a young painter in a 1600's Bruges workshop? Maybe a 1950's supermarket clerk or a 1980's police officer? Would you visit a theme park in 1930's or a cathedral in the year 1000? Some occupations are obviously more delightful in some eras... but with skill and patience you can transfer attitudes and possibilities from one era to another.
The possibilities are endless and the only choices to make are based on taste... is the world a nice place to live in or gets nicer by the actions of your lively character/characters?

Long story short: the atmosphere is just as important as the narrative, if not the more important one (see Michael Crichton for fine blend of these factors). Yes, this involves a lot of research, but you are researching something you love, right? Know thyself :)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
3. Be careful when setting up conflict
Today we are bombarded with media (movies, computer games, interpretation) where well-defined intersts enforce what is allowed to happen. They can't be pro-good because they are evil, they can't be pro-beauty because they are repulsively ugly, and they can't tell the truth because their existence relies on lying. This restricts their options to
>“bad” guy does something I don't like him doing so the “good” guy punishes him/her
which is basically 99.995% of plots in media.

I will list some random, more or less abstract, alternatives to jog your imagination:
>accident vs. restoration / reparation (towards TGBD that is)
>crime vs. solving crime (something real, not “racism”)
>invasion / disease vs. cleansing
>threat vs. preparation for facing the threat
>chase vs. evasion (vs. retaliation or revenge)
>invention vs. consequences (responsibility!)
>boredom vs. travel/exploration
>making rules or contracts vs. respecting said rules or contracts
>making a mistake vs. facing a fair but demanding judgement
>assuming individual responsibility vs. committee
>asking permission vs. fulfilling conditions set
>granting permission vs. supervising execution
>loneliness vs. organizing a party
All these can be focused on individually or even combined... or altogether ignored, choosing a mosaic of tableaus instead.

Long story short: While all narrative relies on conflict or drama (rise... fall... rise and fall... rise, fall, rise... see Vonnegut's “Six Basic Plots”) you can be as conventional or unconventional as you like. The question is what you really want. What fits you? Where do you fit? What will you gift to the world?
Read Evola's books for more ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
4. Essence vs. Existence
This is the last point I will make. Communists say “if you were in his or her place, you would have acted the same”. I say that this is bullshit. The essence of man is the seed that makes him unique. It's not a consistent set of behaviours, but the actual generator of those behaviours. Each time you learn something, you combine it with the seed... and even if the effect is subtle, it's always there. The same seed in a different environment may develop an other pattern, an other behaviour... but that pattern (behaviour) is not guarenteed to be some cliché written in the sociology texbook your communist teacher crams down your neck. On the contrary, concordance happens only in people who are very similar in essence, like negroes.

This means that if you want to have a realistic and lively character, you will have to balance his or her essence (4.) with the values we discussed (1.), the environment he or she is in (2.), and the actual narrative from which he or shedraws his or her energy (3.)

It may sound complicated, but it's dead simple as that's what any “character” actually is: they
being in a certain situation (3.) they have certain physical possibilities, depending on their physical and social environment (2.), and from those possibilities they choose the ones most in line with both their values (1.) and their essence (4.).
Contrary to what the schools teach us, there are no “complex” or “simple” characters, “bad” or “good” characters, “main” or “secondary” characters... but only characters whom the reader would befriend and characters the reader would rather avoid. It's really that simple.

Beside the environment and the essence there is also divine inspiration, but that is a private (“esoteric”) matter so I couldn't go into it even if I tried.

Long story short: the only transformation characters can go through is trusting themselves and getting closer and closer to their essence.

>Can anyone project/shift/have an out of body experience?
Yes.

>Is it not just a vivid lucid dream?
No. A full successful astral projection/shift/oobe feels just as, and often even more real than the waking reality you're experiencing right now. The difference between this and even extremely vivid lucid dreams is absolutely huge.

>Does it have to be difficult and take me months/years to attain this ability?
No, it does not, the only barrier is your mind - both conscious and subconscious. If you think it's going to be difficult, it will. Many people can be successful within their first few tries.

>How come? And how is even this connected to astral travel?
There exists an infinite amount of realities with infinite "you's" into which you can focus your conscious awareness. Astral projection and other OOBEs are, in essence, the same thing - projecting your consciousness into the Astral Plane etc.

>Do I have to come back?
Not from shifting.
Yes from projecting, but also somewhat up for debate.

>Does this have anything to do with the teenager trend spreading on TikTok and in other places?
Yes and no. Kids latching onto an idea they may not even understand, pay them no attention.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33839173
>any advice on breaking through the stage im stuck on
Most powerful technique is to manipulate your subconscious mind through denial of desires. For example, make it a point that you'll eat no more food until you astral project, once you finally AP you can eat again. You could also do this with sexual gratification, internet, water, anything that has powerful urges connected to it, you deny that desire and tell yourself the only way to get what you want is to astral project. The point is creating as much stress as possible within the subconscious, resulting in powerful subconscious motivation to AP, which is especially important because it's highly probable that right now you're subconsciously resistant to AP.

What techniques you use in combination with this isn't super important, it's only important that you practice them as often as possible. What's most likely going to happen is you're going to fall asleep at some point during this process and your subconscious will do the work for you, you'll wake up right into the mind awake body asleep/vibratory stage and that's when the work you've put towards practicing separation will be most useful

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33820441
Body asleep, mind awake.

Lay down, almost like you're about to fall asleep. Get into to a comfortable position. Next, close your eyes and keep your mind awake while your body drifts asleep.

The key part about keeping your mind awake is this: it doesn't mean staying alert. Body asleep. Mind awake. Sit back, and relax. Don't think too hard, let thoughts come to you. You will be laying down on your bed, and the thoughts will come to you bubbling into your mind. Let them grow. Look at them, focus on them. Eventually, images, and sounds will form. Peer into those. Walk into it, as if you were walking with your body.

And there you have it!

All existence bears the quality of "Being", the fundamental Prima Materia for all reality. It has never been made, nor shall it be unmade, and has survived and will survive, indefinitely. I remember the formation of my identity cluster, which means what preceded me had the capacity of memory. I am aware of a ring of fire, a portal filled rather literally with screaming, dread, and a sense of perfect torment which my essence filtered into this world through. I brought with me nightmares of my family being butchered every night, being dragged into hell (as early as 3) repeatedly, and heightened paranormal/poltergeist activity to my home.

I often wonder if I'm exactly human, or what "human" really means, in light of theories where the body is merely clothing for a deeper, 'more real' entity.

In this, I am not alone - I'm barely special. The world is littered with people who share this form of seeming displacement, in the way prison is typically populated by people who committed crime within a certain threshold and peppered with people who barely deserve to be there and people who should be on death row.

But I say all that, to say that death is a complex and ill understood phenomenon, because we all CAME from Death. Death is our Mother going in, and coming back, and her womb is the sacred city of all sages, all enlightened - and it's no surprise how occulted it is from mortal understanding.

I have seen that place, where the living do not go. You will too. And you will be transformed, by the turning of the Great Wheel.

>>33892334
That's just your ridiculous frivolous assumption that God would abandon the animals He made.

In the first creation story man and woman are created in God’s image and He decided to let humans govern all animals. But it also tells us that animals have a soul. In Genesis 1:30 it reads,

And to every beast of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is life, I have given every green herb for meat: and it was so.

This describes animals having hayyah (life). However, in the Hebrew it also has the word nephesh in combination with hayyah, which is the exact same wording as the description of the soul in the creation of Adam in Genesis 2:7. In other words, though nephesh is only translated as “life” here, the Hebrew speaks of the soul. Animals thus have a nephesh hayyah just like Adam.

Nephesh hayyah is also used to describe all the sea animals and flying creatures Yahweh created in Genesis 1:20-21. Genesis 1:24 says that cattle, creeping things, and beasts also have a nephesh hayyah, as well as fish in Leviticus 11:10.
If people dismiss the idea of animals having a soul because the Bible does not explicitly depict God breathing the soul into animals, like He did with Adam, we could argue that women do not have a soul either since it does not say that God breathed the nephesh into Eve.
The Bible is riddled with passages where animals, as well as nature, praise God. You can find it in the Psalms, Isaiah, and the Book of Revelation among many places. It suggests that all of God’s creation are aware of God.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33892436
>>33892334
Cont.

An illustration of this is the story of Balaam’s donkey. It demonstrates that animals are far more than soul-less animated beings. Balaam is called the “wicked prophet” because, though he knew God, he betrayed Him. The king of Moab asked Balaam to go and pronounce curses over Israel in return for money. Balaam was unable to fulfill that order because Yahweh had blessed Israel. Eventually he found a roundabout way to invoke God’s anger against Israel by enticing Israel to sin. However, while on his assignment, Balaam rides his donkey when she—the donkey—sees the angel of the LORD standing in the way. Three times the donkey had to sidestep the angel and each time Balaam hit her because he could not see the angel. Then Yahweh “opened the mouth of the donkey” (Num. 22:28) and she asked Balaam what she had done for him to hit her. Balaam answered that she made a mockery of him. Then he said that if he had a sword, he would kill her. The donkey responds that Balaam has ridden her all his life and asked if she had ever acted like that before. Balaam answered “no” (Num. 22:30). Then Yahweh opened Balaam’s eyes and he was able to see the angel of the LORD with a sword in his hand. Balaam bowed down and fell on his face. The angel of the LORD asked why he struck the donkey three times and said that he came to stand in his way because his way was perverse “before me” (as the angel is a representation of Yahweh), (Num. 22:32). He proceeded to say that, “If she had not turned away, I would certainly have killed you by now, but I would have spared her.” (Num. 22:33).

Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33892334
>>33892436
>>33892450
Note here that the donkey could see the angel of the LORD without God opening her eyes, unlike Balaam. This implies that animals, arguably because of their innocence, can see the spirit world all the time. Humans can only do so when God makes an exception just as it was an exception for the donkey to speak in human language. Most of all, this illustrates the ignorance of the human, Balaam, rather than the donkey. He wanted to kill the donkey only to find out that she had saved his life. The angel of the LORD even specified that he would have killed Balaam, but not the donkey, had the donkey not avoided the angel (Num. 22:33). In other words, Yahweh defended the life of an animal before a human who was in the wrong.

Cont.

One instance where the content of the story tells us that animals have a soul is God’s covenant with Noah and his descendants. Yahweh laid down the (rain) bow, which was the sign of a warrior, as a promise to never flood the earth again. However, He also made this covenant with all the animals. In fact, He made it between Him and the entire earth (Gen. 9:13). Why would God make a covenant with any entity or being that does not have consciousness, which is a trait of the soul? A covenant is a two-way affair.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33892463
Cont.

Some say that people in Biblical times did not have pets and therefore did not view them as we do today. This oversimplifies things. People who had farm animals and used them to travel also had a relationship with them just like people do today. The story of Balaam’s donkey is one illustration in the Bible and Alexander the Great and his horse Bucephalus is another example from Biblical times. Cats in ancient Egypt were domesticated and highly revered and in India cows were, and still are, sacred. Horses are one of the most important animals in history and they play an important role in the Book of Revelation. They are featured in Revelation 6:1-8 carrying the four horsemen of the Apocalypse. In what is commonly understood as Jesus’ second coming (chapter 19) he returns riding on a white horse and is followed by his army who also rides white horses while clad in white linen (v. 14) to signify purity. Horses carried warriors and in Revelation it serves as a contrast to when Jesus rode into Jerusalem on a donkey. Contrary to popular belief that this was a sign of meekness and humility, it was the sign of kingship and riding in the name of peace. Horses, as well as donkeys, were not just a feature in the Bible like a piece of clothing. They are co-warriors in the coming Apocalypse, co-workers on farms, and in this way companions, living up to the original purpose God gave them during creation. We cannot be companions with someone who does not have a soul.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33892471
Cont.

I will conclude with a passage from Job which is one of the most powerful books in the Bible. Job declares God’s omnipotence and says in 12:7-10,

“But ask the beasts, and they will teach you; the birds of the air, and they will tell you; or the plants of the earth, and they will teach you; and the fish of the sea will declare to you. Who among all these does not know that the hand of the LORD has done this? In his hand is the life of every living thing and the breath of all mankind.”

In the very last sentence the word “life” is in Hebrew nephesh while “breath” is ruah. It verifies, yet again, that animals have a soul. Most of all, it tells us that all animals know more than many humans about the one thing that matters the most: all life comes from God and our lives are in His hands, and His hands alone. We have a lot to learn from animals.

Among those who are in Crete, and in the township of Athens, and in the isle of Aegina and Euboea, famous for ships, in Aegae and Eiresiae and Peparethus near the sea, in Thracian Athos and Pelion’s towering heights and Thracian Samos and the shady hills of Ida, in Scyros and Phocaea and the high hill of Autocane and fair-lying Imbros and smouldering Lemnos and rich Lesbos, home of Macar, the son of Aeolus, and Chios, brightest of all the isles that lie in the sea, and craggy Mimas and the heights of Corycus and gleaming Claros and the sheer hill of Aesagea and watered Samos and the steep heights of Mycale, in Miletus and Cos, the city of Meropian men, and steep Cnidos and windy Carpathos, in Naxos and Paros and rocky Rhenaea—so far roamed Leto in travail with the god who shoots afar, to see if any land would be willing to make a dwelling for her son. But they greatly trembled and feared, and none, not even the richest of them, dared receive Phoebus, until queenly Leto set foot on Delos and uttered winged words and asked her:

“Delos, if you would be willing to be the abode of my son Phoebus Apollo and make him a rich temple—; for no other will touch you, as you will find: and I think you will never be rich in oxen and sheep, nor bear vintage nor yet produce plants abundantly. But if you have the temple of far-shooting Apollo, all men will bring you hecatombs and gather here, and incessant savour of rich sacrifice will always arise, and you will feed those who dwell in you from the hand of strangers; for truly your own soil is not rich.”
